### Load packages and data


```{r load-packages, message = FALSE}
library(tidyverse) 
library(dsbox) 
```

```{r load-data, message = FALSE}
states <- read_csv("data/states.csv")
```

### Exercise 1

```{r dimensions of Dennys dataset}
nrow(dennys)
ncol(dennys)
dim(dennys)
```
The Denny's dataset has 1,643 rows and 6 columns. Each row represents a Denny's location. The variables are: address, city, state, zip, longitude, and latitude. 

### Exercise 2

```{r dimensions of Laquinta dataset}
nrow(laquinta)
ncol(laquinta)
dim(laquinta)
```
The La Quinta dataset has 909 rows and 6 columns. Each row represents a La Quinta location. The variables are: address, city, state, zip, longitude, and latitude. 

### Exercise 3

There are La Quinta locations in Canada, Mexico, China, New Zealand, Georgia (the country), Turkiye, the United Arab Emirates, Colombia, and Ecuador. There are no Denny's locations outside of the United States. 

### Exercise 4

To find a location outside the US using just the data, you could filter for any location that either has no state or an abbreviated state that does not match any of the states of the USA. 

### Exercise 5

```{r Filter for states that are not in states$abbreviation}
dennys %>%
  filter(!(state %in% states$abbreviation))
```
There are no Denny's locations outside of the US.

### Exercise 7

Based on the website, there are La Quinta locations in Canada: British Columbia (Kelowna and Richmond), and Ontario (Oshawa). In Mexico: Aguascalientes, Ciudad Juarez, Poza Rica, Puebla, Reynosa, and San Jose Chiapa. In China: Chengdu, Qionghai, Suzhou, Taiyuan, Turpan, Weifang, and Zunyi. In New Zealand: Auckland and Queenstown. In Georgia: Batumi. In Turkiye: Bodrum, Cesme, Giresun, and Istanbul. In United Arab Emirates: Abu Dhabi and Dubai. In Colombia: Medellin. In Ecuador: Quito. 

### Exercise 8

```{r adding country variable and storing}
laquinta <- laquinta %>%
  mutate(country = case_when(
    state %in% state.abb ~ "United States",
    state %in% c("ON", "BC") ~ "Canada",
    state == "ANT" ~ "Colombia",
    state == "FM" ~ "Honduras",
    state %in% c("AG", "CH", "PU", "SL", "QR", "NL", "VE") ~ "Mexico"
  ))
```

```{r filter laquinta locations}
laquinta <- laquinta %>% 
  filter(country == "United States")
```


### Exercise 9

```{r calculate dennys locations by state}
dennys %>% 
  count(state, name = "n") %>% 
  arrange(n)
```

Delaware has the fewest Denny's locations and California, Texas, and Florida has the most. 

```{r calculate la quinta locations by state}
laquinta %>% 
  count(state, name = "n") %>% 
  arrange(n)
```

Maine has the fewest La Quinta locations and California, Texas, and Florida has the most. 

It is not surprising to me that the most populous states have the most locations and the lesser populous states have the least. 


```{r}
dennys %>%
  count(state) %>%
  inner_join(states, by = c("state" = "abbreviation"))
```

### Exercise 10

```{r most locations per 1000 sq miles for dennys}
dennys %>%
  count(state) %>%
  inner_join(states, by = c("state" = "abbreviation")) %>% 
  mutate(dennys_per_1000sqmi = n / (area / 1000)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(dennys_per_1000sqmi))
```

DC, RI, and CA have the most Denny's locations per thousand sq. miles.

```{r most locations per 1000 sq miles for la quinta}
laquinta %>%
  count(state) %>%
  inner_join(states, by = c("state" = "abbreviation")) %>% 
  mutate(dennys_per_1000sqmi = n / (area / 1000)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(dennys_per_1000sqmi))
```

RI, FL, and CT have the most La Quinta locations per thousand sq. miles.
